Protein crystallization generally consists of an initial screen followed by optimization of promising conditions
Whereas the initial screen typically uses a standard set of premade crystallization cocktails optimization requires new cocktails with small perturbations of the original composition
Asynchronous crystallization robots can create crystallization cocktails from stock solutions but in practice this ability is rarely exploited
Instead largescale operations typically use a general liquidhandling robot to create optimization screens whereas academics mostly rely on manual optimization
This approach avoids the complex integration of hardware software and dataflow between two robots and saves cost and space
